comments.author: pkauf

comments.text: The thing is that you need to have the heated bed at high temperatures (for PET I use 90°C) and no unintended airflow like from open windows around the print area. The arms have quite a large print area. This is especially problematic if you print with full top and bottom infills. The forces appearing during the uneven cooldown of the print object will rip the object from your print bed.
comments.author: pkauf

comments.text: I'm using PLA (Hatchbox) at 65 for first layer, 60 rest.  I am only printing the Left arm right now as I had a ton of issues with it pulling up.  Finally gave up and used glue and it made it hold.  No open windows.  This is my first printer (Prusa I3 MK2S).  What is the problem around "full top and bottom" infills?  Where would I go to change that, and what do you suggest?  Was the around the comments you made about using the honeycomb and leaving it open for looks?  FYI, using Prusa's version of SLIC3R.
comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text: I haven't printed with PLA for a while now because in my opinion PETG the perfect balance between the excellent properties of PLA and ABS with just a few to none of their drawbacks. Just my opinion!

I did print this with Honeycomb but left the bottom/top layers as default.  What do you set for speed?  Could this be printing too fast?

comments.text: As you have the MK2S and you are using Slic3r Prusa Edition, the default speed setting should be almost perfect.

comments.text: You're welcome! We all had started printing at some point in our life and had to learn a lot. Now, printing is more of an intuition thing than of hard fact science. comments.text:
Martin,
The dimensions of the frames on the Mark 2 and Mark 3 printers are the same. There is no reason the arms should not fit properly on either printer. The only issue with the Mark 1 and 2 arms is the clearance between the frame and the print carriage was reduced because Prusa added parts to the carriage that were not there before.

comments.text: OK, this is a bit radical ... but ... have you considered placing the brackets on the inside of the spool? i.e. swapping the left and the right components, making the whole assembly much narrower. Silly idea. If you flip around the arms, they are just as wide, because of the Nut components. The Arm components are just as wide as the Nut components, so there is no savings in width.

comments.text: I have been using this spool holder for six months now and it is great. One interesting thing I have come across is that the rollers, when printed in PLA, are harder than the rims of the spools, which are typically made from ABS. As a result, there is some wear of the spool rim in the form of black dust and fine threads that accumulates on the rollers. Once some fell off into my print. I plan to try sanding the surface of the rollers to remove the print layer lines, which I think will make them less abrasive.
comments.author: mdkendall

comments.text: Hi, I printed out the part that the bearing goes into, how tight should the bearing be? I put the 608 bearing into the first one that I printed, it did go in but was decently hard to get into it (I had to bang it a few times to get it in there, but not too hard). I then printed the part again, 1% larger and It now fits in easier but is not a super tight fit. I am unfamiliar with how bearings should fit, so before I print off the other 7 would be great to know which one I should go with. Thanks!

Followed your instructions and had great results until it loosen. On my second try i managed to make it stick with some calibration and glue on the bed. But i get some strange stringing when the nozzle lifts up and moves, like a smal top that will be in the way on the next round of layer. Temp at 210 and bed at 55. Speed and fan at default, (like 60mm/s on perimeters and 80mm/s on infill, fan at 35-100% and disabel for the first 3 layers it think it says) Any tips on temp, speed or fan-speed?
comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text:
Your "small top" is the result of over extrusion and a leaky nozzle.
You will have to reduce the material flow labeled "Extrusion multiplier" in slic3r"s Filament Settings menu.
This can become a science of its own, but you can start simply by reducing the value by about 10%. Say from 1.0 to 0.9.

comments.text: I printed the "MK1" version and it worked well...too well. I had the experience of the loose filament slipping outside of the spool borders. It seems to occur in particular prints where the print nozzle moves in the widest X-axis range as it will easily pull the filament from the spool on the left and right ends of the X-axis but when moving to the middle, it pushes the filament back causing a lot of loose filament slack and the loose filament can then slip outside of the spool borders, particularly on full spools where the windings are already near the spool edges.
comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text: If this is a reoccurring issue for you, try using a spool guide, like this one:
comments.author: Protopix

comments.text: Bear in mind that this issue only happened because my spool was full beyond the normal. Certainly after use about 8mm (in the diameter of the filament in the spool) this will be no issue.
comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text: I printed the MK2 versions for my new Prusa i3 mk2 printer. I really like how these turned out! The fit is very snug with the bolts in the frame, but the nuts screw onto the bolts smoothly and with barely any effort. Very well designed! The brackets themselves fit tightly to the metal frame of my Prusa i3 mk2, with no wobble or looseness at all. It may loosen over time, as I have to move them based on different spool widths, but I doubt it will be by much. The only item that caused me some slight concern is how tight the fit is for the bearings inside the wheels. I had to use a metal punch and tap them into place with a hammer to get them in as far as intended. I'm certain that it would take the same to remove them later. But that's something that can be adjusted by sizing the part before printing, not a concern of the design itself. These were the third things I've printed after assembling my printer from the kit, so I just used all of the defaults it came with. Printed beautifully! The only thing that might be nice would be a hole to store the filament end when not using the spool, like in the first design. But that's easy enough to add with a drill bit too ;). Awesome work Martin!

title: 3D Scanner - Converted Sliding Bar for Tripod Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have seen many different rigs for Kinect or ASUS Xtion scanners. Most of them required a massive tower structure to allow for the vertical adjustment of the scanner.  
To improve my current 3D scanning setup using my existing tripod, I came up with this idea of incorporating an off-the-shelf shower sliding bar with a standard shelving unit back support, to allow for the vertical adjustment while the entire build can still be kept minimal and portable.  
I know the parts that I designed won't fit everyone else's tripod, and it depends on what you can find from your local hardware store, but I think with minor tweaking they should work for you as well.

Audiophiles, here is a little known fact about Sugru. Moulding this wonder material into cones for your speakers will isolate sound vibrations, meaning you get nicer tunes and fewer complaints from the neighbours. Not just technically impressive, they look pretty darn good too.

You could easily mould these clever little rubber feet by hand, but for the perfectionists among us, we’ve designed this 3D printed mould so you can produce precision cones yourself.

GET STARTED
All you need to create these rubber feet for your speakers is a 3D printed mould, 4 packs of Sugru, a paintbrush and some dish soap (washing up liquid).

There are several options for getting your mits on your own 3D printed mould and you need never own a 3D printer.

1: Order the parts from a local independent 3D printer through the very awesome 3D Hubs. This is the fast budget option, we use this service all the time and love it. Just download this file and upload it to 3DHubs.com. You could also bring the file to a local Hack Space!

1: Order your mould directly from Shapeways. These guys print in an incredible range of materials and print resolutions. If the surface finish is important to you, this might be the best option. This does come at a cost though.

STEP 1:

  • Paint a light coat of soapy water (that’s just a drop of dish soap in water) onto the inside of the mould and shake off the excess.

STEP 2:

  • Use just half a pack of Sugru per foot - roll it into a ball and press it into the mould and press into a cone shape.

STEP 3:

  • Press the Sugru slowly and firmly onto your speaker and twist gently from side to side.
  • Sugru should extrude through the hole in the top of the mould and out the sides. Remove this excess Sugru.

STEP 4:

  • Gently lift off the mould to reveal a perfectly formed Speaker foot. Repeat for all 4 feet per speaker.
  • Clean the excess Sugru with a dry tissue.
  • Leave to set for 24 hours.

That's it! Share the mould with your friends or think about other objects that you could put these rubber feet onto...
Buy 1mm copper wire from DAISO and fit them into the print.

title: Velleman k8200 (3Drag) z-axis lead screw upgrade

description.text:
These parts allow you to use a lead screw from Aliexpress ( https://goo.gl/yncjzu (the KP08 version)) instead of the standard 8mm threaded rod. This gets rid of the ugly lines that you can see every couple of layers with some printers. As the 8mm lead screw is really similar to the threaded rod, the conversion is very easy and cheap.

Here is my video on it: https://youtu.be/myBAhWnsvrY

Supports:

No

Infill:

70-100%

This bin for dishwasher tabs I built to have the tabs always ready to grab.
It is a very simple design with a unique wall thickness of 2mm.
The bottom of the bin has several openings to avoid any accumulation of dust or particles of the tabs staying in this bin.

Check out the building process on Youtube:

title: HDB Support (Head Development Board Support) for FABtotum

description.text:
This is a printable support for HDB, Head Development Board for the FABtotum Personal Fabricator.
It is necessary if you don't want to use the original covers contained in the head development kit (eg: you have to make something bigger).

After printing, remove the 4 small supports that hold up the teeth of the support.

The Board, the lasercut aluminium support and the orginal covers can be purchased as a kit here:
https://store.fabtotum.com/eu/products/head-development-kit.html

To find the details about the communication protocol, sample sketches and documentation, check the github page: https://github.com/FABtotum/Head-Development-Kit

Edit (16/11/16): Updated version with correct scale factor.

If you want to win at life, you will download this dice and have the 3D printer print it ASAP. Let's just say, it's worth the investment.

title: CNC Y Axis Mini Mill X2

description.text:
Was not going to publish this, But to many people asked me in forums! so back tracking to make videos since this been in use for 2 years now! Y axis build Video is found below along with the other Axis parts!

All Parts where printed in PLA at .2 layers and .2 head size. 30% fill. I use the hand cranks on my mini mill to align the parts for the cnc operation. You could mill objects with the hand cranks fine as long as your not to rough on it. It's mini mill so slow is the game anyhow! I may do a MACH3 Setup Video also Shortly!

2X 6MM WASHERS
2X 6MM LOCK WASHERS
1X 28OD X 12MM WIDE X 12MM CENTER ID BERARING
1x 5/16 or 8mm locking nut!

"ONE SIDE NOTE*

ON THE TOP OF THE BEARING BLOCK THERE IS A HOLE!!!!
THEN USE A SHORT SCREW TO PLUG IT! THIS WILL BE HOW YOU CAN GET OIL TO THE BEARING WITHOUT TAKING IT ALL APART! I

title: Chuwi Hi8 pro - Power Up Case

description.text:
My opinion:
The wonderful low-price tablet paired with a low-power battery, for me in the long term an unacceptable condition. This tablet is extremely versatile and powerful, try it absolutely. Wow, Android 5.1 and Windows10, with a total of 32GB memory plus SD card optional up to 128GB. If this tablet is set up and well configured, then you have a reliable companion for everyday life. Price and performance here are almost upper class.

But this under-sized integrated battery spoils the fun of the thing.

This is why it is now available for every DIY hobbyist:
The Chuwi Hi8pro PowerUp Case. Nearly twice the battery power for everyone.

But beware:
All technical changes to the hardware are your own responsibility, and may result in the loss of any warranty. Handle with the electronic hardware and especially with Li-Ion / Li-Poly accumulators can cause dangerous situations despite all caution. In case of doubt, please be advised and supported by qualified persons if you lack the necessary knowledge for a perfect procedure.

Before publishing:
I have tested everything carefully and over a period of several weeks. So I found this modification to be good and safe. Nevertheless, I take no responsibility at this point!

Please also download the picture package:
There you will find (...without many words) as far as self-explanatory further information about the modification of the Chuwi Hi8 pro Tablet.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

@0.1mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

Minadax PLA 2.85mm @45mm/s @200 degrees Celsius

Apart from suitable tools, you also need:
  • Fundamentals of electronics and soldering experience.
  • Different types of li-Ion / Li-Polymer batteries with Protection-Board and a maximum dimension of 4mm x 119.5mm x 171mm.
  • A suitable connector m/w, for example MR30 + Silicone cable, suitable for currents up to a maximum of 3 amperes.
  • Hot glue.
  • heat shrink tubing.
  • foam rubber buffer with a thickness of 5mm.

Insufficient battery power...
  • Without Modifikation:

(+) Narrow and handy housing.
(+) Low weight including battery.
(-/+) Below average good battery performance. But low charging time until completion.
(+) Protective covers officially available.
(-) Battery difficult to access and complicated to replace.

  • After Modifikation:

(+/-) Still a very handy device. But now a total of 16 mm thick. On each housing side it is only a plus of 1.5mm thickness.
(-) Total weight of the tablet without original battery...275g...plus nearly...60...grams for the power case, plus the weight of the selected new battery...150g...Total weight: ~485 Grams.
(+/-) Nearly twice the battery power. But a much longer charging time until completion.
(-/+) No protective covers officially available. But the 3D printed case provides some protection for the device housing and the new battery.
(+/-) Different types of batteries with a maximum of 4mm x 119.5mm x 171mm selectable and easily interchangeable. But always a suitable connecting plug must be soldered.

  • Always keep your modifications in mind:
    !!! Do not use batteries without protective electronics (BMS-BatteryManagementSystem). Unprotected batteries with direct polarity connections are absolutely unsuitable and extremely risky in this application !!!

  • Attention:
    !!! Never leave your active tablet unattended. It is possible that thermal problems can not be completely excluded. For example, an excessive use of the device during the charging process, or generally an unintentionally high system load over an extended period of time, can result in overheating and burning of the new battery !!!

author: 9Harry99

description.text:
This project is an adapter for a cheap usb microscope, allowing to accurately focus the object.

It provides a vertical slider, holding the microscope, and a removable tray.

More details/pictures/though process can be found in the related blog post: http://www.revelut.ch/2016/12/16/building-a-microscope/

The project is fully designed in Fusion 360 and can be viewed/forked here : http://a360.co/2d3W5Ab (might help for assembly) and recombined into an svg

Cut everything out of 3mm mdf, cut chunk of an m6 threaded rod
Assemble the sliding part (small ring on the bottom, bigger hole on top), glue n M6 nut
Assemble the sliders into body
Insert the sliding carriage the put the threaded rod in place, add 2 nuts on top of the carriage
Finish glueing the body (top and back)
Use the 2 nuts to prevent the rod from getting out (hence forcing the carriage to slide down rather than the rod to go up)
Profit :-)

title: Orion Atlas EQ-G Latitude Adjustment Handle

description.text: T-Handle to fit over the Orion Atlas EQ-G latitude adjustment levers. Slides on with no modification to the mount, makes adjusting latitude much easier. Slides right back off when not in use.

author: kraegar

description.text:
Center point for woodworking.
To mark the center for dowel pin.
Material:PLA
Photograph is the one when it is used for SPF. It worked fine.
And it is enough for DIY use, I think.
But typically center points is made by metal. So You can not use this for hard wood, but can use for soft wood.

This stove knob was designed for our Pelgrim 950.1 stove.
A little reinforcement was made to fix the reason why the original parts broke over time.

The part was printed using PETG.
Nozzle temp 232
Bed temp 50
put a little glue on the heated bed.

Enjoy!
